title: Toddler, 2, badly burned after knocking coffee off table onto himself
text:
Laura Jakes’ son Arthur suffered severe burns after grabbing a a hot cup of coffee (Picture: Laura Jakes)

A two-year-old boy was left with severe burns on his arm and chest after grabbing a cup of hot coffee and spilling it on himself.

Laura Jakes, from Cambridgeshire, shared distressing images of the damage caused to her son Arthur’s body to warn other parents about the dangers of hot drinks.

She said the cup of coffee was ’15 minutes old’ but caused devastating injuries within seconds.

Laura told ITV: ‘It’s devastating when it does happen. It was a fifteen-minute-old cup of coffee. It was pushed way back on the side, so he managed to climb up and grab it.

‘I never though a cup of coffee could cause such damage as what it has to Arthur.’

Arthur Jakes burnt the left side of his body after grabbing hot coffee (Picture: Laura Jakes)

Laura wants to raise awareness about the damage hot drinks can cause to children (Picture: Laura Jakes)

Laura shared her story ahead of a new campaign to raise awareness about treating children with burns.

NHS figures reveal 35,000 children have required specialist care for burns in the last five years, with 30 babies and toddlers going to hospital with a hot drink burn every day.

Plastic surgeons from the college and the British Burn Association are warning that children can face years of ‘grueling’ operations after suffering burns that are entirely preventable.

Andrew Williams, a consultant plastic surgeon at Chelsea and Westminster Hospital in London, who specialises in burns, said: ‘All it takes is for a small child to pull a kettle cord, or knock a cup of tea over, and they can be scarred for life.

Experts have warned that thousands of children suffer burns like Arthurs’ (Picture: Laura Jakes)

Hot food and drink are the main cause of burns in children (Picture: Laura Jakes)

‘Every second counts when it comes to treating a new burn, so it is vital that parents know basic first aid – especially the importance of running scalded skin under cold water, for example.’

Experts say the way a burn is treated in the initial seconds and minutes after is ‘crucial’

Fadi Issa, consultant plastic surgeon at the regional burns unit at Stoke Mandeville Hospital, said: ‘Our advice is simple: 15-20-25.

‘Run the scalded or burned skin under water at 15C for 20 minutes – and you could reduce the depth of a burn by up to 25%.

‘This treatment can convert a deep burn needing surgery to one that just needs simple dressings to heal.

Burns can require grueling operations and cause life long scarring (Picture: Laura Jakes)

Laura Jakes wants to raise awareness about burns (Picture: Laura Jakes)

‘The other key information is not to put any lotions or potions on a cooled burn.

‘Cover it in cling film and seek urgent medical assistance.’

Among the advice to parents is running cold water in a bath or sink before adding cold water, keeping saucepans at the back of the stove rather than the front, and keeping hot drinks out of a child’s reach.

Experts also say children should never be left unattended in a kitchen.

description: Hot drinks warning as figures reveal thousands of kids scalded each year
